awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MLWiNS: Distributed Learning over Multi-Access Channels: From Bandlimited Coordinate Descent to Gradient Sketching
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent wave of technological advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence has led to widespread applications and public awareness. At the same time, the rapid growth of high-speed wireless network services presents an opportunity for future distributed learning involving a vast number of smart IoT devices. This project targets several technical challenges posed by the limited reliability of wireless connections and computational constraints of the edge nodes in distributed learning systems. Overcoming these challenges is vital to the plethora of computation, communication, and coordination tasks required by distributed machine learning at the network edge. Centered on developing innovative edge learning algorithms over wireless MAC channels under the constraints of computing, power, and bandwidth, this project can significantly impact wireless edge learning in a variety of IoT applications, ranging from transportation, safety, and agriculture, to energy efficiency, e-health, and smart infrastructure. The broader impact of this research will also come through many educational opportunities by providing opportunities in STEM to K-12, women, and underrepresented minority students.  


This collaborative project will develop an innovative network architecture for distributed learning over wireless multi-access channels. Specifically, the PIs will take a principled approach to develop an integrated wireless edge learning framework, using both gradient-based methods and also very recent advances in gradient-free, zero-order optimization, while taking into account the constraints in computing, power and bandwidth therein, in a holistic manner. The developed methods will be also extended to the setting of distributed online learning and reinforcement learning under wireless MAC. The PIs will focus on optimizing communication-efficient gradient sparsification based local updates that are communicated within the wireless network under bandwidth constraints; and each sender intelligently carries out transmission power allocation based on learning gradient and channel conditions. One important objective is to develop a novel learning-based framework for efficient wireless channel estimation and update to enable effective power control and learning. The project will devise edge learning algorithms that are robust against wireless channel uncertainty. The team of PIs shall comprehensively investigate the impact of the wireless bandwidth and power constraint on both the accuracy and convergence speed of edge learning algorithms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project tackled a timely and challenging question: how can we enable intelligent, data-driven learning and decision-making in distributed systems—like fleets of robots or networks of sensors—where communication is unreliable and computing resources are limited? Motivated by real-world needs ranging from environmental monitoring to smart cities, we developed a suite of theoretical and practical tools to help autonomous agents learn, communicate, and cooperate effectively.

Our work made contributions across multiple fronts:

1. Learning with Minimal Communication in Distributed Systems
We designed new learning algorithms that work even when agents can’t reliably share data or gradients due to bandwidth constraints or wireless interference. These algorithms used techniques like compressed sensing and sketching to efficiently transmit information across multi-access wireless channels. We demonstrated how agents can still achieve accurate and fast learning with reduced communication costs, a breakthrough with relevance to both AI and wireless networking communities.

2. Model-Free and Feedback-Based Optimization
Many real-world systems—such as power grids or robotic teams—don’t give agents clean, mathematical descriptions of how their actions influence outcomes. To address this, we developed zero-order and feedback optimization methods, which let agents improve performance using only the outcomes of their actions, without needing explicit models. These techniques were shown to be effective in problems like voltage control, resource allocation, and collaborative sensor planning.

3. Learning in Multi-Agent Physical Environments
Our team developed algorithms to handle complex scenarios in which multiple robots or agents must work together to complete tasks, such as locating a light source or covering a large area. For instance:

  • We proposed an information-driven source-seeking algorithm where robots share local measurements to estimate a target’s location, improving accuracy and speed while remaining robust to noise and model uncertainty.
  • We developed a multi-agent Bayesian optimization algorithm for learning and maximizing unknown functions efficiently. This was particularly useful in scenarios where physical experiments (like robotic motion) are costly or time-constrained.
  • We introduced a new coverage control algorithm that takes into account the energy and time costs of agents moving between sensing locations—an important consideration for real-world deployment.

All of these methods were not only analyzed theoretically but also validated on a physical multi-robot platform using TurtleBots and Crazyflies in our lab.

Broader Impacts
This project trained and mentored a diverse group of students and postdocs, including undergraduates, graduate students, and one high school student. One PhD student has graduated under the supervision of this project and three undergraduates has graduated and continued to purse PhD degress on related area. It supported new educational experiences, such as the creation of an active-learning control course and robotics activities for K-12 students—particularly girls in public elementary schools. Our research findings were widely shared through publications, conference talks, and open-access codebases. In addition, insights from this project have been applied in fields such as wireless networks, federated learning, robotics, smart grids, and environmental sensing.
